filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of a digital edition of forty-three pencil drawings produced by Blake during his first decade as an independent artist, 1779-1790. Drawing lies at the core of Blake's life as an artist. Pencil was his preferred medium for sketching—more flexible, less expensive, and more easily corrected than pen and ink or chalk. Preliminary work with the pencil preceded more finished work, either as separate sketches for prints and paintings or as drawings underlying water colors. Blake's nineteenth-century writings on the arts testify to his conviction that drawing was fundamental to all pictorial expression: "The distinction that is made in modern times between a Painting and a Drawing proceeds from ignorance of art. The merit of a Picture is the same as the merit of a Drawing" (*A Descriptive Catalogue*, Erdman page 549); "Let a Man who has made a Drawing go on & on & he will produce a Picture or Painting but if he chooses to leave off before he has spoild it he will Do a Better Thing[.]" (*Public Address*, Erdman page 576); "Painting is Drawing on Canvas & Engraving is Drawing on Copper & Nothing Else…& he who Draws best must be the best Artist…." (*Public Address*, Erdman page 582); "Dear Sir, excuse my enthusiasm or rather madness, for I am really drunk with intellectual vision whenever I take a pencil or graver into my hand…." (letter to William Hayley, 1804, Erdman page 757).
Blake no doubt executed a great many more pencil drawings than those extant today. Sketches were not intended for exhibition or sale; most were probably discarded, while others may have been retained only because of more developed compositions on the other side of the leaves. Even the slightest and least aesthetically ambitious drawings offer insights into the origins and earliest realizations of Blake’s designs. These first thoughts on paper often tell us more about Blake’s habits of mind, when joined by eye and hand, than more finished works. Sketches are “the first fruits of [Blake’s] imagination,” as Geoffrey Keynes states in the introduction to his *Pencil Drawings of William Blake* (1927).
The forty-three pencil drawings presented here, produced in Blake’s first decade as an independent artist, show his early debt to academic standards of precise copying and to the neoclassical emphasis on outline. The first four works may have been drawn while Blake was a student in the Royal Academy schools. Other sketches are preliminaries for some of Blake’s most important designs. Among these are the *Study for “Glad Day”, or “Albion Rose”* (Object 6), Blake’s iconic vision of the human form divine in energetic pose, and three sketches (Objects 34-36) for illustrations to *Tiriel*, the only group of finished drawings Blake composed for one of his own poems. Several sketches are early efforts at picturing events in the Bible, Blake’s main inspiration for designs throughout his life. This biblical cluster includes *The Resurrection of the Dead* (Object 10), *Samuel Presenting Saul to the People* (Object 15), and *Job’s Wife and Other Sketches* (Object 31). Other studies, such as *Ugolino in Prison* and its verso (Objects 21-22), reveal the beginnings of subjects also of lifelong interest for Blake. Only a few drawings for Blake’s illuminated books have survived, but studies such as *Sketches for “The Book of Thel”* and *A Standing and a Recumbent Figure* (Objects 37-39) offer fascinating glimpses into Blake’s methods of graphic production and revision.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

desc.objtitle: A Group of Figures Round a Table and a Seated Old Man, object 1 (Butlin 223 verso)

objnote.p: The recto of this leaf is a pencil drawing datable to c. 1793, *A Figure Bending Over a Corpse in the Rain, with further Bodies Behind, Possibly for the Title-Page of "America"*. The pencil letters lower right, "J D F," are the initials of John Deffett Francis, the first recorded owner of the drawing. This inscription may have been written by Francis. The British Museum collection stamp appears upper right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two vertical lines in the center of the drawing divide the compositional space into two seemingly unrelated halves. At right, a bearded and gowned man with long hair sits in a chair facing forward. His bent left arm rests on the arm of the chair (obscured by his drapery), and he points down with the index finger of his left hand. His right arm is extended and his right hand rests on his left knee; the index finger of his right hand is extended down and to the right. Both legs are bent and spread. An object whose significance is indeterminate is visible below his right foot. In the scene at left, four figures sit and stand around a table. The rightmost figure is an adult woman with long curly hair wearing a gown and veil who sits in a chair. Facing forward, she bends her left arm upward to hold a distaff and her right arm is bent and raised across her torso; she holds the material she is spinning with both hands. The spindle(?) to which the material is still attached rests on the table in front of her. Beside the female figure at left, a smaller male figure, perhaps a child or adolescent depicted from the waist up, is visible. He has short curly hair and wears a long-sleeved shirt. Both of his arms rest on the table, and he appears to rest his head on his raised right hand. A second smaller male figure stands in the foreground, across the table from his companions, facing right. He has short curly hair and wears a shirt with tights or breeches. His bent left arm rests on the table and his right is at his side, slightly bent. He stands in contrapposto with left leg extended backward, heel raised. Visible from the shoulders up, the leftmost figure of the group is an adult male figure with a beard. He faces right and wears a hat with a ribbon. This group may be a family with a father, mother, and two male children. The table around which they sit is round with one visible serpentine leg. Two tall arched openings that may be doors or windows are visible in the right side of the wall behind the group at left. Framing lines extend around three sides of the composition and include the seated figure far right.

component.illusobjdesc: At right, a bearded and gowned man with long curly hair sits in a chair facing forward. His bent left arm rests on the arm of the chair (which is obscured by his drapery). He points down with the index finger of his left hand. His right arm is extended, and his right hand rests on his left knee; the index finger of his right hand is extended down and to the right. Both legs are bent and spread. He may wear tights or breeches as well as shoes. An object whose significance is indeterminate is visible below his right foot.

The chair on which the figure at far right sits is almost entirely covered by his drapery; however, two straight legs are partially visible at right. Horizontal lines below the figure indicate a floor.
A group of four figures—an adult male, an adult female, and two male children or adolescents—sit around a table in the scene at left. They may represent a family.

Four figures sit and stand around a table in the scene at left. The rightmost figure is an adult woman with long curly hair wearing a gown and veil who sits in a chair. Facing forward with head turned slightly left, she bends her left arm upward to hold a distaff and her right arm is bent and raised across her torso; she holds the material she is spinning with both hands. Her right leg is crossed over her left with the heel of her right foot raised almost vertically off the ground. If this group represents a family, she is likely the mother.
The female figure at left holds a distaff in her left hand. With both hands, she spins thread, which is attached to the spindle(?) visible on the table in front of her.
The female figure at left sits in a chair. One of the chair legs is visible front right.

Four figures sit or stand around a table in the scene at left. The second figure from the right in this group is a smaller male figure, perhaps a child or adolescent, depicted from the waist up. He has short curly hair and wears a long-sleeved shirt. Both of his arms rest on the table, left crossed over right, and he appears to rest his head on his raised right hand. His eyes are raised.

Four figures sit or stand around a table in the scene at left. A male figure, who may be a child or adolescent, stands in the foreground, across the table from his companions, facing right with head turned down. He has short curly hair and wears a shirt with tights or breeches. His bent left arm rests on the table and his right is at his side, slightly bent. He stands in contrapposto (or perhaps leans on the table) with left leg extended backward, heel raised.

Four figures sit or stand around a table in the scene at left. Visible from the shoulders up, the leftmost figure of the group is an adult male figure with a beard. He faces right and wears a hat with a ribbon. If this group represents a family, he is likely the father.
The table around which the four figures sit in the scene at left is round with one visible, rather serpentine leg.
Two tall arched openings are visible in the right side of the wall behind the group at left. These may be doors or windows.
Framing lines extend around three sides of the composition and include the seated figure far right.
